Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Direct-in-liquid electrical discharge for the production of hydrogen-rich gas

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
1336385/1336173
Mededovich/Kovaleski

Manufacturing of hydrogen from hydrocarbons is needed for a variety of applications, especially for fuel cell powered vehicles and plasma treatment of exhaust gas. Though plasma-assisted reforming of gaseous hydrocarbons provides several advantages over conventional reforming technologies, creating plasmas directly in liquid hydrocarbons can potentially lead to smaller size and higher throughput reaction vessels with product selectivity different from the plasma formed in gaseous hydrocarbons. This project investigates the fundamental chemical processes occurring during direct-in-liquid plasma-assisted reforming of liquid hydrocarbons and alcohols. The experimental work uses radical scavenging techniques, plasma spectroscopy, as well as deuterated and isotopically labeled solvents to elucidate chemical pathways responsible for the formation of hydrogen, short-chained hydrocarbons, and syngas during direct reforming of liquid fuels with and without water or air. The theoretical effort focuses on the development of kinetic models for electrical discharges in ethanol and in iso-octane with the purpose of comparing theoretical (i.e. predicted) and experimental byproducts. The work also extends to the characterization of the discharge using fast optical imaging, schlieren and shadowgraphic imaging, and interferometry. The project and its related activities directly engage undergraduate and graduate students, extend to local elementary school students, and educate the general public.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Manufacturing of hydrogen from hydrocarbons is needed for a variety of applications, especially for the production of hydrogen-rich gas for fuel cell powered vehicles and plasma treatment of exhaust gas. Compared to other reforming technologies, electrical discharge plasmas provide several advantages including fast response time, durability, compactness, low weight, and high conversion efficiencies. However, to maximize the conversion of hydrocarbons and increase the byproduct selectivity, it is important to elucidate chemical reaction mechanisms and develop complete reaction schemes.

This project investigated the fundamental chemical process occurring during plasma-assisted reforming of liquid hydrocarbons and alcohols using direct-in-liquid pulsed streamer-like electrical discharges. Experiments were conducted in a wide range of liquid organic precursors including diesel and gasoline and a range of experimental techniques have been applied to elucidate chemical reactions responsible for the formation of stable gaseous and liquid byproducts under different experimental conditions. For some liquids, density function theory simulations were used to determine the most probable reactions responsible for the formation of experimentally measured byproducts.

Electrical discharges decompose organic liquids into CO and CO2 (if oxygen is present in the starting mixture), H2 and short-chained hydrocarbons. A variety of new and unusual organic liquid compounds, previously unknown, were detected in the treated liquids. The thermal decomposition was consistently the most critical pathway for the production of gaseous and liquid products from this process independent of the initial solution composition compared to electron reactions. Therefore, the initial solution composition had a significantly greater effect on the reaction mechanism than any other investigated parameter. Nevertheless, for all the liquids, an increase in the applied voltage corresponded to an increase in the selectivity for each gas and liquid product as these conditions produced plasma with the largest volume (i.e., reaction zone) and temperature. High voltage electrode polarity and electrode material played a minor role in the chemical reaction stoichiometry for all the liquids. Bubbling argon through the plasma decreased the production rates of all the species. Bubbling oxygen and air increased the production of oxygenated species and added to the chemical reaction complexity.

In oxygenated organic liquids, H2 is primarily formed through hydrogen radical abstraction reactions. CO is formed exclusively through the complete thermal decomposition of the starting liquid and can be converted to CO2 through the gas-water shift reaction. The hydrocarbon gases and larger liquid products are produced from recombination reactions of carbon-based radicals. In liquid hydrocarbons, H2 is also formed through hydrogen radical recombination and abstraction reactions while the hydrocarbon gases are formed through the pyrolysis of the staring compound. The majority of the liquid products formed in pentane and higher hydrocarbons are produced by radical recombination reactions of >C5 precursors yielding compounds significantly larger than the starting hydrocarbon.  

The project answered fundamental questions regarding the effects of the starting liquid composition and presence of additives (e.g., external gases) on reaction stoichiometry and syngas production, explained differences in the chemical reactivity among non-aromatic hydrocarbons, partially-aromatic and non-aromatic compounds, assessed the ability of electrical discharge plasmas to crack long-chained hydrocarbons and aromatic compounds into short-chained hydrocarbons, and elucidated chemical reaction pathways for the production of key gas and liquid byproducts.

This project supported one PhD student and two undergraduate students. The PI educated elementary school students and general public in plasma science and engineering. The work resulted in 18 products.

 

 


Last Modified: 11/27/2017
Modified by: Selma Mededovic
